title: 113_hr4756
content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying. A local educational agency must report bullying incidents within 7 business days, detailing the acts, any protected characteristics involved, and the response by agency employees. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying incidents. A local educational agency must designate an individual to receive reports of bullying, inform employees of the contact information, and report incidents within 60 days of receipt. An exception allows employees not to report bullying if a student requests confidentiality. The "BRAVE Act" requires a designated individual in a local educational agency to inform employees of contact information for reporting bullying incidents. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform all employees of the acts reported and their responses, excluding any student's identifiable information. Additionally, the agency must publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and employee responses for students and parents. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to provide quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and employee responses, excluding any student's identifiable information. Agencies must also conduct an annual review of bullying policies for schools under their jurisdiction. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to annually review bullying policies for schools and provide quarterly reports on bullying incidents and responses, excluding personally identifiable information. As a condition of receiving funds, agencies must certify compliance with the Act and submit the four most recent quarterly reports. The Office of Civil Rights will establish a procedure for receiving complaints from students or parents. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Education will establish a procedure for receiving complaints related to non-compliance with the "BRAVE Act" from students, parents, or other individuals. Upon receiving a complaint, the Assistant Secretary will investigate to determine if a local educational agency failed to comply with the Act. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights will investigate complaints of non-compliance with the "BRAVE Act" by local educational agencies. If non-compliance is found, actions such as withholding funds, issuing a cease and desist order, or entering into a compliance agreement may be taken, similar to actions authorized under the General Education Provisions Act. Information about complaints will be made publicly available. The Assistant Secretary will investigate complaints of non-compliance with the "BRAVE Act" by local educational agencies. If non-compliance is found, actions such as withholding funds, issuing a cease and desist order, or entering into a compliance agreement may be taken, similar to actions authorized under the General Education Provisions Act. Information about complaints will be made publicly available on the Department of Education's website. The section defines bullying as severe, pervasive, or persistent acts causing harm or concern towards another student, leading them to withdraw from school activities. It also includes protected characteristics like race, gender, and disability.
